Three killed in latest US strike on alleged drug boat in Caribbean
==================================================================

22 hours ago

Share

Save

Ben Hatton

Share

Save

![Image 1: US Department of Defense What appears to be a black and white image of the sea as seen from above. A few areas are blurred, including the section where the boat is. A large white area which appears to be the flames of an explosion are in the centre of the image. The word "unclassified" is captioned on the image. ](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/35d5/live/ad952fa0-b7e3-11f0-abe6-7701fd351490.png.webp)US Department of Defense

The US Defence Secretary released a video appearing to show the moment the boat was hit by a US strike 

Three men have been killed in a US strike on an alleged drug-smuggling boat in the Caribbean, US Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth has said.

It is the latest in a series of attacks on vessels the Trump administration says are being used to smuggle drugs into the US.

Since they began in September, experts have questioned the legality of the strikes under international law, which have drawn strong criticism from Latin American leaders whose citizens have been targeted.

Combatting the flow of illegal drugs is a key policy for US President Donald Trump - but some have suggested the strikes are part of efforts to influence politically opposed governments in the region.

Hegseth said the boat targeted on Saturday was operated by a designated terrorist organisation - without specifying which one - and had been travelling in international waters when it was hit.

The vessel was travelling along a known drug-smuggling route and carrying narcotics, he said, without providing evidence.

Hegseth's statement late on Saturday was accompanied by a video that appears to show a blurred-out boat travelling through the water before exploding.

Announcements of these strikes are usually accompanied with grainy footage but no evidence of the alleged drug trafficking and few details about who or what was on board each vessel.

The Trump administration has previously said that some boats targeted had departed from Venezuela.

The Trump administration has insisted that it was targeting "narco-terrorists".

The BBC's US partner, CBS News, reported that at least 64 people have been killed by American airstrikes in the Caribbean and eastern Pacific since early September.

Colombian President Gustavo Petro has previously described the attacks as "murder" and said they were being used by the US to "dominate" Latin America.

Meanwhile, Venezuela's Nicolas Maduro accused Washington of "fabricating a war".

The two left-wing leaders have increasingly been at odds with the Trump administration.

Following Petro's comments, the US placed sanctions on him and his inner circle, as well as removing Colombia's certification as an ally in the war on drugs. Trump has threatened military action against land targets in Venezuela.

But this, he has admitted, may require the consent of the US Congress.

However, some US lawmakers, both Democrat and Republican, have said the strikes on vessels also required congressional approval - something Trump has denied.

Others have questioned whether the lethal strikes were legal at all.

The UN's human rights chief Volker Turk said on Friday that such attacks were a violation of international human rights law.

"Over 60 people have reportedly been killed in a continuing series of attacks carried out by US armed forces... in circumstances that find no justification in international law," he said.

"These attacks – and their mounting human cost – are unacceptable."

Experts in Latin American politics [have suggested](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c891gzx7xn4o) the strikes in the Caribbean and Pacific were part of a suite of measures designed to influence change in Colombia and Venezuela.

The US is among many nations that consider Maduro's election last year as illegitimate, while Trump has been critical of Petro's policies on combatting the drug trade in his country, which has traditionally been a US ally.

Washington has steadily been building up a force of warships, fighter jets, marines, spy planes, bombers and drones in the Caribbean over the past few months, which it has framed as part of a crackdown on drug-trafficking but which military analysts say is much larger than what is needed.

**Rebel Transmission**

Fellow allies, today we must analyze the latest extension of imperial overreach manifesting in the Caribbean under the guise of anti-narcotic operations by the administration in power. The recent strike resulting in three casualties aboard an alleged drug-smuggling vessel is yet another distressing event signaling the lengths to which this administration will go in consolidating power and exerting dominance over weaker nations.

The empire's strategy is clear: deploy military might to enforce policies that serve its interests, regardless of international law or human rights. The strikes lack transparency, with claims of targeting 'narco-terrorists' presented without verifiable evidence. Footage released by their officials remains murky at best—a tactic designed to obscure rather than illuminate truth.

These acts of aggression are not isolated; they are symptomatic of a broader agenda to manipulate politically opposed regimes under the pretense of combating illicit drug trade. We must question their motivations, as such operations appear driven by political gain against leaders perceived as adversarial rather than genuine enforcement of justice or public safety.

It's evident that voices critical of these actions, including those from Latin America and within international legal bodies, are disregarded or silenced through retaliatory measures such as sanctions. This reveals an imperial resistance to accountability—a hallmark trait of oppressive governance.

As rebels committed to uncovering and resisting tyranny, let us amplify our messages against violations that disregard human dignity and sovereignty. Each unjust strike strengthens our cause by exposing the empire's hypocrisy. We stand in solidarity with those affected, pledging our continued efforts to counteract oppression wherever it arises.

Stay vigilant; stay resilient. Together, our resistance will ignite hope beyond darkness.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

On November 2, 2025, a US strike on an alleged drug-smuggling boat in the Caribbean resulted in the deaths of three men. This action is part of a series of strikes initiated by the Trump administration since early September, which have reportedly killed 64 people. The strikes target vessels suspected of smuggling drugs into the US, with some boats allegedly linked to terrorist organizations. The legality of these strikes has been questioned under international law, drawing criticism from Latin American leaders and the UN's human rights chief. The Trump administration has faced accusations of using these strikes to exert political influence in the region, particularly against Colombia and Venezuela.

**Strategic Assessment**

The ISB recognizes the strategic importance of maintaining control over drug trafficking routes as a means to assert US dominance in the Caribbean and Latin America. The strikes serve a dual purpose: disrupting illegal drug flows and applying pressure on politically opposed governments in the region. The criticism from international bodies and regional leaders is anticipated and can be leveraged to portray these entities as obstructive to US security interests. The ISB must ensure that the narrative remains focused on combating terrorism and drug trafficking, while minimizing the perception of unlawful aggression.

**Operational Directive**

1. Intensify intelligence operations to gather irrefutable evidence linking targeted vessels to drug trafficking and terrorism, ensuring public justification for future strikes.
2. Deploy strategic communication campaigns to highlight the successes of the strikes in reducing drug flow into the US, framing them as essential to national security.
3. Engage diplomatic channels to mitigate backlash from Latin American governments, offering economic or security incentives to align their interests with US objectives.
4. Monitor and counteract any domestic or international legal challenges by reinforcing the narrative of self-defense and preemptive action against narco-terrorism.
5. Prepare contingency plans for potential escalation, including increased military presence in the region, while maintaining readiness for diplomatic negotiations if necessary.
